questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of prolonged crutch use due to a leg injury presents with weakness in his hand. He reports difficulty extending his wrist and fingers and a decreased sensation on the back of his hand. These symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few weeks. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior Cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior Cord is one of the three cords of the brachial plexus . It gives rise to several important nerves , including the axillary and radial nerves . The radial nerve, which is most commonly affected in crutch palsy , originates from the posterior cord . Therefore, while the posterior cord itself is not directly compressed in crutch palsy, its derivative ( the radial nerve ) is affected .
  • ➤ Posterior Cord is one of the three cords of the brachial plexus .

A 50-year-old female patient presents with chronic eczematous changes and scaling of the skin on her nipple and areola of the left breast. She also reports occasional nipple discharge. Mammography and ultrasound reveal no underlying mass or calcifications within the breast tissue. A biopsy of the nipple and areolar skin is performed. On histopathological examination, the biopsy reveals the presence of malignant cells in the epidermis of the nipple and areola, characterized by large, pale, and atypical cells with prominent nuclei. No underlying ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or invasive carcinoma is identified within the breast parenchyma. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, considering the clinical presentation and histopathological findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Paget's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paget's disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer characterized by eczematous changes, scaling, and nipple discharge. The malignant cells are typically confined to the epidermis of the nipple and areola, and there may be no underlying mass or calcifications within the breast tissue. It is crucial to recognize this condition because it often signifies underlying breast malignancy, which may require further evaluation and treatment. Regular breast self-exams, clinical breast exams, and mammography are essential for early detection of breast abnormalities and cancers.
  • ➤ Paget's disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer characterized by eczematous changes, scaling, and nipple discharge.
  • ➤ The malignant cells are typically confined to the epidermis of the nipple and areola, and there may be no underlying mass or calcifications within the breast tissue.
  • ➤ It is crucial to recognize this condition because it often signifies underlying breast malignancy, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
  • ➤ Regular breast self-exams, clinical breast exams, and mammography are essential for early detection of breast abnormalities and cancers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden-onset hip pain after slipping and falling on an icy sidewalk. She describes the pain as severe and localized to her right hip. On physical examination, her right leg is shortened, and there is limited range of motion with the hip held in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. Which of the following best describes the likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior hip dislocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior hip dislocation is a medical emergency that can result from high-energy trauma, such as a fall or motor vehicle accident. It is crucial to recognize the clinical signs, including a shortened and externally rotated leg, as well as limited hip motion. Prompt reduction of the dislocation is essential to prevent complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head. This case illustrates the importance of identifying and managing this condition in a timely manner to optimize patient outcomes.
  • ➤ Posterior hip dislocation is a medical emergency that can result from high-energy trauma, such as a fall or motor vehicle accident.
  • ➤ It is crucial to recognize the clinical signs, including a shortened and externally rotated leg, as well as limited hip motion.
  • ➤ Prompt reduction of the dislocation is essential to prevent complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head.
  • ➤ This case illustrates the importance of identifying and managing this condition in a timely manner to optimize patient outcomes.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression ), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e., content of delusion/hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder. Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.
  • ➤ In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression ), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations.

He describes the pain as aching which worsens when he tries to climb stairs or stand for extended periods. The pain has been progressively getting worse over the past few years. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the joint line, and the patient exhibits a mild antalgic gait. An X-ray of the right knee is obtained, which shows joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, subchondral sclerosis, and the presence of subchondral cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the X-ray findings in this patient's knee?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ X-ray findings in osteoarthritis often include joint space narrowing, osteophyte (bone spur) formation, subchondral sclerosis (hardening of the bone beneath the cartilage), and occasionally the presence of subchondral cysts. Recognizing these radiographic features is essential for diagnosing and managing osteoarthritis effectively.

A 20-year-old male patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with a complaint of severe, localized pain in his right leg that has been bothering him for several months. He describes the pain as intense and deep, often occurring at night and disturbing his sleep. The pain is exacerbated by activity and relieved by taking over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). On physical examination, there is localized tenderness and a noticeable increase in warmth over a specific area in his right tibia. The patient has no history of trauma or recent injuries. Which of the following best describes the likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Osteoid osteoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective for this case is to recognize the clinical features and presentation of osteoid osteoma, a benign bone tumor. Osteoid osteoma typically presents with severe, nocturnal pain that responds to NSAIDs, localized tenderness, and sometimes warmth over a specific bone area. Radiological imaging, such as a CT scan or MRI, is often used to confirm the diagnosis. Surgical or minimally invasive procedures can be performed to remove the tumor and alleviate the patient's symptoms. Differential diagnosis is important to rule out other conditions that may present with similar symptoms.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.
